I applaud the committee's passage of this provision within the STRONG Veterans Act and look forward to continuing my work to push this vital effort that will help our nation's heroes across the finish line. (5/5)

These specialists support fellow veterans and encourage recovery, helping their peers to access health services and navigate the VA health care system while also teaching coping and positive health-affirming behaviors. (4/5)

By harnessing peer-to-peer relationships and applying their own lived experience, peer counseling specialists play a vital role in combatting risks of veteran suicide and treating mental health conditions. (3/5)

The Veteran Peer Specialist Act builds on the program we established in the 2018 VA MISSION Act by permanently expanding access to veterans' best guide to care: fellow veterans. (2/5)

Over 150 officers were injured during the insurrection. Many more carry invisible scars caused by the trauma they were subjected to that day.

On this difficult anniversary, I'm sending prayers and gratitude to these heroes and their families.

Today we remember US Capitol Police Officer Brian Sicknick, who died in the line of duty, and Officers Jeffrey Smith, Howard Liebengood, Gunther Hashida, and Kyle DeFreytag, who died by suicide in the months following the attack.

The service and sacrifices made by @CapitolPolice and @DCPoliceDept officers to defend the Capitol on Jan. 6 will never be forgotten.

The American people deserve answers and will not forget how their representatives responded in this moment. I remain committed to protecting the sacred cornerstones of America‚Äôs democracy and will not let up until all involved are brought to justice. (7/7)

The only way to ensure our democratic institutions survive is to ensure accountability. Democrats and the handful of Republicans who have put aside partisan differences will continue investigating the details of January 6, 2021. (6/7)

However, when it came time for them to take real action, each cowered to Trump. Even now, they push lies that the election was rigged, scoff at what should be a united effort to learn the truth & refuse to take steps to prevent such an act of terror from happening again. (5/7)

Many Republican leaders that day‚ÄîVP Mike Pence, Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell, House Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy, Minority Whip Steve Scalise & others‚Äîdenounced the mob & correctly called it one of the darkest days in American history. (4/7)

It was later, once safely evacuated, that I understood the true gravity of what was occurring: a violent, concerted effort to stop the certification ceremony that would affirm 2020‚Äôs electoral votes. It was an attack on the Constitution, our democratic systems & the nation. (3/7)

I was in the House gallery when the first insurrectionists breached the Capitol. At the time, those of us in the chamber had no clue what was happening. I thought a few rogues pushed through the metal detector until I heard a bang that sounded like gunfire or tear gas. (2/7)

On the anniversary of Jan. 6, we are reminded that our democracy requires both political parties' fearless participation & resolve. It saddens me to see how Republican leadership was too scared to stand up for America when we needed them most. (1/7)

Other provisions eliminate loopholes, promote competition, and fight the exploitation of patients by placing fair checks on insurers, manufacturers, and drug companies. (12/12)

Click here to learn about my plan with @RepSchrader to lower drug costs: https://t.co/oFZXAvnhNj

Our bill works to lower prices at the pharmacy counter while preserving America‚Äôs unparalleled medical science ecosystem. We want the talent and know-how that has developed therapies and cures and the amazing COVID-19 vaccines to stay on our shores. (11/12)

As price-setting scares off investment, it threatens jobs in American science, especially in my district where the life sciences industry employs about 27k San Diegans. (10/12) https://t.co/MgORPV2BtZ

If we signal to investors through price setting that they may not be able to recoup their investment not only for their successes, but also their failures, they‚Äôll invest elsewhere & we may well lose our ability to find cures to the toughest and rarest chronic diseases. (9/12)

In 2018 alone, private investment funded $102 billion of US drug development ‚Äì dwarfing the budget of the NIH, and without risk to taxpayers. The cycle of risking private investment in research and development for a return down the line has generated great results. (8/12)

This bill also protects America's ability to find life-saving cures.

The @USCBO found that, accounting for failures, the cost to bring a drug to market could be as high as $2 billion. That‚Äôs for just one drug or treatment. (7/12) https://t.co/VMl6py73ha

The Reduced Costs & Continued Cures Act empowers Medicare to negotiate with manufacturers to bring down the cost of expensive treatments when competition fails (i.e. no generic or biosimilar has been marketed & the initial period of exclusivity has expired for a product). (6/12)
